content: No, a life peer cannot become a lord temporal because the two are different types of peers. As mentioned earlier, a life peer is appointed for life by the monarch based on their expertise in a particular field. In contrast, a lord temporal is a hereditary peer who has inherited their title and is a member of one of the five ranks of the peerage. Once a person is made a life peer, they are not eligible to inherit a hereditary title, and therefore are unable to become a lord temporal. However, there have been cases of hereditary peers who have been appointed as life peers, and they are permitted to sit in the House of Lords as life peers.
